We are totally opposed to the new water tax. We believe it would be far better to spend €1 billion mending the broken water system which loses 40 per cent of water each year than spending €1 Billion on installing meters. We stopped the introduction of water charges in the North of Ireland.

Our position is very clear; we opposed the property tax and would scrap it because it is an unfair tax on the family home. We would replace it with a Wealth Tax on assets over €1 million. We would also reintroduce the non-principal private residence tax on second properties.

The Board of Management of each school and the parents of the children attending the school should be involved in any changes to do with patronage . After all it is the parents choice of school to begin with and their child it will affect.
This issue needs urgent attention , at the moment the system is not working . Engagement with all sides is the only way forward .
All efforts should be made to resolve any anti social behaviour issues with engagement with the people involved and the people affected by this issue.
This should be looked at carefully ,With the correct consultation with the people of the towns and anybody affected by the building of the bypass.

A strong city centre is vital for growth for the county as a whole , this should be a priority for the new council and a plan is in place to ensure this happens with part of the UL campus being brought to the city centre. This will have huge benefits for business locally.

The naming of the bridge should be put to the people of Limerick , It should never have taken up the time of the council in the way in which it did. I as strongly against it being called the JFK Bridge in this way.
As the city centre is being improved and new plans put in place to bring more people into the centre this may work but as with all planning ,meaningful consultation is the key to success here.
The Mayor of Limerick under the new council is now a symbolic role / office . If people would like to directly elect the Mayor of Limerick , I would support that.

The cost has to play a part in using local referendums to decide issues as they can be costly . A better way maybe to ask the public using a survey together with social media and consultation with the councillors , as referendums as expensive to run.
It should never be about male and female when selecting candidates , It is about ability and the person bring put forward being credible , honest and hard working to represent the people .
For water pollution reasons
Most are of inferior quality
Water infrastructure needs massive investment
This money is needed for investment in the area
Rates are already too high. City centre is declining while shopping centres are booming
They should be allowed to supplement benefits by working for local authority

It is a human right to have a decent place to live and building good quality social housing is the answer to the housing crisis. Labour Party, Housing Minister Jan O'Sullivan is providing €27 million of funding to Regeneration in Limerick each year with the bulk of that money spent on retrofitting houses and bringing forward new housing developments similar to the recently completed schemes at Cliona Park, Moyross and Colivet Drive, Southill.

The hundreds of millions paid to private landlords in rent allowance each year represents poor value for the state. We should borrow specifically to embark on an extensive plan to build sufficient numbers of good quality Council houses creating jobs in construction and providing proper homes for families. Within twenty years the scheme will pay for itself rather than continuing to transfer enormous amounts of state resources to private landlords.

The development of villages in rural areas represents better planning instead of granting planning to one off houses each with their own septic tanks. A better outcome is achieved, the rural landscape is preserved and a better sense of community can be fostered and services can be provided on a more economic and environmentally friendly basis.

Each estate must be assessed individually. Where a ghost estate is in an accessible location and where the houses are in reasonable repair and where it is economically viable, representing good value for the state, they should be taken over by the local authority and completed to provide housing. However if the location is unsuitable and the houses are in a poor state of repair, demolition is appropriate.

The Labour Party is pro-active in government in opposing a standing charge and ensuring that provision is made to minimise the amount charged to vulnerable sectors of society. Water rates will lead to conservation and the programme of network replacement should be accelerated.

The amount by which LPT can be raised or reduced by councillors is limited within a band of 15% up or down. It is Labour Party policy to reduce it where possible, however any reduction must be assessed in terms of the impact on cuts to essential services that would have a negative impact on the quality of life in the city.

Next year 80% of LPT will be spent where it is collected with 20% paid into a central fund to support poorer local authority areas. This will encourage greater interest in local government as people will be concerned as to how their tax is being spent, to see that funds are not being wasted and that they are getting value for money and receiving services in their locality in return.

Poor consumer spending in Limerick since 2008 has impacted on retail in the city. Quality retail provides employment and must be protected to make the city more attractive to shoppers and to attract investment and tourism. Further reductions in rates are needed and commercial rates should be revised to take greater account of turnover rather than the outdated property valuation system that penalises people who invest in their outlets.
Sufficient funding should be allocated to the provision of accommodation for settled people and for Travellers to ensure that all members of society have decent housing.

As a founder in 1989 of the multi-denominational primary school, the Limerick School Project, on O'Connell Avenue, I believe that there is a demand and that more local primary and secondary schools should be multi-denominational and that religious instruction should be the responsibility of churches outside school hours. More work should be done to provide families with multi-denominational options appropriate to a pluralist society.

An enormous amount of money has been spent annually for many years impounding horses and the problem of neglect and cruelty to horses persists. Impounding of horses where appropriate should continue, however a new approach supporting the setting up of horse projects by providing land on the outskirts of the city should be tried, promoting regulation and education, working in partnership with horse owners along the lines of the model that has been very successful at Dunsink in Dublin.
I have marched in Gay Pride Parades and supported the vote in Limerick City Council earlier this year for same sex marriage. Council should continue to support this festival promoting equality.
After a process and if the behaviour is persistent, in order to protect law abiding residents and tenants

The county town with which I am most familiar is Adare. The through traffic contributes nothing to the town and only leads to frustrating congestion. Towns like Adare will develop as more attractive places to visit if through traffic is eliminated and journey times will be improved for motorists trucks drivers etc. who are just passing through. The local and overall economy will benefit.
If wind farms are properly located and do not impact negatively on the environment they represent a valuable renewable energy resource.
Another charge is difficult for people to pay at this point and while metering will encourage water conservation leaking pipes must be replaced also.

More people should cycle to reduce their carbon footprint and for economic and health benefits. Public transport should be made more attractive for similar reasons and to relieve traffic congestion in the city. I voted in support of of the Ballinacurra Bus Lane now nearing completion. Bus lanes also facilitate ambulances, taxis and Garda cars making roads safer.
The cultural, historic and retail centre of the city must be vibrant to attract investment, tourism and employment that will be of benefit to the city and the county.
I am supporting the introduction of "pay and display" in the city as a more effective method of paying for on street parking.

Increased pedestrianisation works and makes the city more attractive to visit for shopping, leisure, festivals, etc.. This can involve wider footpaths with reduced lanes for vehicular traffic as on Thomas Street, Catherine Street and John's Square and full pedestrianisation at other suitable locations to create pedestrianised public spaces as on Lower Thomas Street and on Bedford Row.

We should not underestimate the Council Manager system that has served the city well and is widely accepted as an form of local government in the US where the Manager is a professionally administrator implementing policy formulated by the elected representatives. Efforts to introduce directly elected mayors in the UK have not been successful. There is a popular tradition in Limerick of the election of a mayor from the elected members on an annual basis.

Councillors are elected for a five year term by the people to represent them and public consultation is in place under planning legislation concerning all major developments. There is also a responsibility on citizens to inform themselves and to participate in these processes to make their views known in that way and by communicating their views directly to their representatives. The process and system already accommodates consultation but is often under utilized.

In our model of democracy there is provision for community groups, residents associations sporting and cultural organisations to lobby support on issues of concern to them and to have their positions advanced by their representatives in Council decision making.

In my opinion it is desirable that more women should be elected and to achieve this goal more women should put themselves forward and the electorate, both men and women should support good women candidates.

Social housing is important as not everyone will ever be able to call a house their home unless there is some government intervention. However a zero tolerance approach should be taken to any anti-social behaviour or criminality to those living in social housing. If these are breached eviction should be the immediate response. Respect to the community is important for social housing recipients.

No by subsidising private landlords we are distorting the rental market and driving prices up. This leads to an investment property bubble at the tax payer's expense. One third of all rental properties receive a rent supplement and this is unsustainable.
One off rural housing is a requisite to ensure we have a vibrant rural lifestyle. However it is impossible to expect the same level of service provision in these areas.
If they have no chance of ever being occupied then they should be demolished and returned to what it was previously zoned for.

Water rates should be enacted as a conservation measure only and any excess usage should be charged at double the cost with the difference ring fenced solely for repairs to the system which leaks 42% of what it produces.
Agree strongly with any reduction in taxation for all.
All of it should be ring-fenced. More specifically in the area it is collected in.
Taxation kills jobs, investment, and will close the doors of the SME's in Limerick. Why would I ever vote to increase rates on jobs if we do not increase the services we provide?
I do not agree with special housing for travellers. We live in a western country where housing like a semi-detached are standard.
It is up to the schools in conjunction with their boards of management to decide on patronage. I would support the continued expansion of Gaelscoil and Educate Together patronages.
All horses kept in urban areas that do not have a licence and a suitable field should be impounded.
Why not? Not for the message it sells which I agree with but for the economic reasons. A council should be about selling our city to any potential tourists.

Working in the Department of Social Protection I have met with first hand to those who have benefitted directly from the Gateway scheme. Many without employment for over 4 years due to no skills available.
The asylum system should be expedited so those applying should not need to work. Short term direct provision would remove this issue. Ireland should not be seen as a soft touch asylum country.
Social housing is a privilege that enables people to get a foot up in our society. It should be treated with respect always. A gift of a home is special.
Adare. Enough said for any commuter regarding this question.
This is a blanket statement that fails to offer options on this complicated issue that varies location to location.
I wouldn't say welcomed but as I have previously outlined it should act as conservation measure only. Not a revenue generator
Yes they should but on auxiliary roads instead of main thoroughfares to prevent disruption like we have seen caused on the Ballinacurra Rd.
It's a reciprocal relationship, when the city is doing well so is the county and vice versa.
No. We are the riverside city and what better symbolises this then naming of a bridge are the vein of our city and country.
I'd love to see free car parking. of course space may an issue but without a doubt should be a goal worked towards.
Again it comes back to removing car parking spaces which are the lifeblood of our city traders. But pedestrianised quays would be a good place to start.
No, it is mainly a ceremonial role.
How many referendums would we need a year? The cost would be huge and if we did this what is the point in having Councillors in the first place.
No but similar to the committee system in the Dáil they should be asked to consult on issues that are relevant to them.
Each party should select the best candidates put forward just like the voters will. Male or female, it should be the best person for the job like any other profession.

We should utilise vacant housing to address the issue of social housing waiting lists in the city and county. We should also look at the improvement of existing social housing. I do not believe more houses will solve the waiting list problem.
I believe, as above, we should look to the transfer of vacant housing to social housing. Rental support may cause disparities in terms of the levels paid and are subject to the rental market prices.
I don't agree. It is anyone's right to build where they wish subject to planning permission. Much of our country is rural and contains one-off houses. This is part of our heritage and culture.

If they are badly placed or built then I agree. If they are not, they should be used to house people on social housing lists. Alternatively, they should be used to provide services such as community/outreach or to address family homelessness

I agree but with stipulations. It must be done by metre estimates so we only pay for what we use and those who can't pay are dealt with individually. I don't agree with a flat rate for everyone. Metres would lead to improved conservation of our water supply. Irish Water should be enshrined in law as a public company so our natural resources cannot be sold to private interests in the future. Also we have to get improved infrastructure for our water supply in return

I agree property tax rates should be reduced because it is not a progressive tax in the sense that it does not take into account people in negative equity etc. Property does not equal wealth in all cases. If this means that we must cut spending in local services then we must review our spending to see where we can cut instead because spending on local services is the most important spending council has to make therefore we should find that money elsewhere
Yes. It comes from the people locally therefore people should see a return.
I don't agree. Limerick City centre is the most deprived in Ireland. We need to encourage business and activity in it.
I agree to an extent. It should be only for a short period in order to get them back into work and to improve PRSI.

Although I don't think there should be party politics in local government, I do believe that gender quotas, for a short period of time, are effective. They should not be a permanent feature but they do, as seen in order developed countries, encourage additional female membership
A Family needs a 'Home' to have security, to grow, to have a sense belonging, to feel love, be cherished and be a part of a community.
Ghosts estates if not habitable for housing should be taken from our landscape, the materials recycled and the land reclaimed for agriculture
It appears that Government have taken the Local Property Tax invested in setting up 'Irish Water' so they can then charge us for Water - Am ! the Wool over whose Eyes !

Firstly we need to get our Property Tax Back. We were promised in the Local Property Tax Act 2012 and by the Government that 80% of property tax would go directly to local service's. - This must happen ! under legislation City & Council councils have the Authority to reduce LPT by 15% Annually
We were promised in the Local Property Tax Act 2012 and by the Government that 80% of your property tax would go directly to local service's. It is ring fenced under legislation

55% of Business rates in Limerick City remained unpaid. Why not half the commercial rates local business's are burdened with and bring the every local business back into the business community. From here the City will Prosper. The commercial rate review currently conducted by the 'Valuations Office effective 2015, www.valoof.ie, is being eagerly awaited by the Limerick Business community
I cannot comment as I'm unsure what the current allocated amount is and how this allocation is currently being disbursed.
The City needs Events. All Sport events are welcome in Sporting Limerick and all Cultural Events are welcome in Limerick City of Culture.

This came in 1990 with the 'New Bridge' which we then called the 'Whistling Bridge' later we thought it was called the 'Condell Bridge' to find out it was actually the 'Shannon Bridge' and now they want to call it the JFK Bridge. Is that five extra Bridges or One Bridge? 'Like A Bridge over Troubled Water'

Sinn Féin Housing spokesperson Dessie Ellis TD: "Local authorities are the best way to solve the (housing) crisis... The other option of hoping private landlords will provide real social housing is pure fantasy."
Sinn Féin prioritises using vacant properties for social housing where possible

"Sinn Féin (is) fundamentally opposed to the introduction of water charges" (Source: Sinn Féin's submission to the consultation on the 'Reform of the Water
  Sector in Ireland')
"The property tax is an unfair, regressive form of taxation" (pre-budget submission 2014)
Sinn Féin's Finance Spokesperson Pearse Doherty has described as "scandalous but unsurprising" the news that the money generated by the Local Property Tax will not go back into local areas

Sinn Féin spokesperson on Environment, Community and Local Government, Brian Stanley TD: "Sinn Féin will introduce a progressive rates system. Progressive rates will take into account profit and turnover the larger companies"

"Many social problems could be solved if local councils met Traveller needs for accommodation in particular. Sinn Féin will use our council positions to make this so" (Sinn Féin local election manifesto 2009)

Sinn Féin Education Spokesperson Seán Crowe says there a "growing demand from parents for choice in different secular/non secular education and it is clear that Minister Ruairí Quinn and the Department of Education and Skills are not responding quickly enough to the many applications that are being made"
Sinn Féin Leader Gerry Adams TD has called for the Gateway scheme, which he termed "exploitation of the long-term unemployed" to be scrapped

Sinn Féin supports strict regulation of wind turbines, including a provision that a minimum distance of ten times the height of the turbine from any dwelling

"Sinn Féin does not support the installation of domestic metering. We support the introduction of district metering. This allows for local authorities to monitor water usage and leakage at neighbourhood level. We are opposed to household charging and therefore metering as a means to measure usage on this basis" (Source: Sinn Féin's submission to the consultation on the 'Reform of the Water
  Sector in Ireland')

Sinn Féin's transport policy includes proposals to legislate for mandatory public transport provision to be factored into all major housing developments; and improvements in quality and quantity of cycle lanes

"Sinn Féin will…reform the structure of local government to make it more accountable – including directly elected Chairs and Mayors who would assume many aspects of the council management oversight role" (local election manifesto 2009)

Sinn Féin will… introduce mechanisms for real community participation in local decision-making and ensure communities and their representative organisations are at the very least meaningfully consulted on major decisions affecting them. Support the establishment of District, Community and Neighbourhood Councils that can formally link with local authorities. (Local election manifesto 2009)

This is one part of the solution.
Rural housing is part of our heritage and culture. Planning decisions should be sensible and take account of the rural landscape and environment.
Ghost estates should be completed and units sold on the private market at reasonable prices. Demand for housing is increasing, we should not be demolishing estates.
LPT rates can only be reduced if Government funds Local Government properly. There cannot be a reduction in local services, although the efficiency of how they are delivered needs to be looked at.
We should not increase rates as this will lead to more business closures, job losses and an even more desolate city centre. Priority needs to be given to assisting viable but vulnerable businesses
Housing waiting lists are increasing again. Current government policy of renting housing clearly doesn't seem to be working.
Councils have dedicated housing professionals. They should be given the responsibility and adequate power to administer a coordinated social housing scheme.
Many Irish people prefer to live close to friends and family. Many prefer to build a home on their own land in the countryside. We don't have a huge tradition of directing people to live in cities.
Complete those can be economically justified. Demolish those that are not viable.
People's ability to pay must be taken into account. Elderly people on fixed income pensions, those that are unable to work, those that cannot find work cannot afford to pay another tax.
Only 54c of every 1euro paid as local property tax returns to Limerick. Central government must fund councils properly in order to provide proper local services
That's how the government sold the introduction of the local property tax to the public. That's not what happened in reality when implemented.

I believe it is more about how the money is spent rather than the amount allocated.

We are totally against the introduction of water rates. The €1 billion spent on installing meters would have been better spent on repairing the current water system that loses 40% of water each year.

Our position is very clear; we opposed the property tax and would scrap it because it is an unfair tax on the family home. We would replace it with a Wealth tax on assets over €1 million. We would also reintroduce the non-principal private residence tax on second properties.
